setup:
An individual can work for up to 60 hours a week at an hourly wage of \(w=90\). The person has utility over weekly consumption \(c\) and weekly leisure hours \(\ell\) given by: $$ u(c, \ell) = c^{ 1 / 3 }\ell^{ 2 / 3 } $$

Calculate the optimal choice of weekly consumption, leisure hours, and working hours.

An individual can work for up to 60 hours a week at an hourly wage of \(w=40\). The person has utility over weekly consumption \(c\) and weekly leisure hours \(\ell\) given by: $$ u(c, \ell) = c^{ 2 / 3 }\ell^{ 1 / 3 } $$

An individual can work for up to 60 hours a week at an hourly rate of \(w=15\). The person has utility over weekly consumption \(c\) and weekly leisure hours \(\ell\) given by the following indifference curves:

1. Draw the budget constraint. Label the optimal choice of consumption and leisure A.

2. Suppose the wage rate changes to \(w=30\). Draw the new budget constraint and label the new optimal choice B.

3. Does the change in wages increase or decrease the number of hours worked?
solution: The change in wage rate did not affect the number of hours worked.
